text: no I think the written word is perfectly
sufficient you know it worked for Kafka
and um if it doesn't work for me it's
only because I'm not good enough with
the written word um I included images in
Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close
because I thought that they were
appropriate for that book um I wanted to
capture the exuberance of this young boy
sort of his maximal imagination also his
imagination's um
desire or need to grasp at lots and lots
of things um September 11th was was the
most visual event probably in human
history it was witnessed by more people
than anything else ever was or has been
and um I thought that there was a a a a
a visual component to the to that event
that couldn't be separated from it you
know when we think about September 11th
we think about the two towers the the
sight of them we think about the plane
going into them the sight of that so um
I thought images were appropriate for
that book I don't think that they are
necessary or appropriate for um every
book or most
books of course it will change and
anybody who thinks it won't is is um not
thinking it through enough you know the
New York Times is now on the iPad right
if the New York Times um didn't have
video embedded in it if you couldn't
link from one article to another if you
couldn't search back issues of the times
if they had a piece about this
unbelievable shot that you know Rafael
Nadal hit and they didn't have a clip of
it we would say that it was being
negligent you know not only that it
wasn't taking advantage of the vehicle
but that it wasn't providing us with the
news that it could and should and so
there's going to be a real pressure on
novels when they start to be read on
screens which seems like an
inevitability to interact with the
vehicle um I don't know what that will
mean I certainly don't know that that's
a good thing at all um there a lot of
reasons to think it's it's a bad thing
but it seems like an inevitability and
um literature has always been slow
slower than the other art forms to
Grapple with um technological changes
cultural changes even you know when you
look at um a book like uh Freedom
Jonathan fransen's most recent book
there are many ways in which it could
resemble the Odyssey you know or
Shakespeare and I think that's one of
the things that people love so much
about it and should love so much about
it but if you look at artists who are
now contemporary artists who are at the
the sort of peak of their game or the
Forefront of their forms um what they
have in common with artists working a
hundred years ago much less a couple
thousand years ago is almost nothing you
know music has changed so much in the
last 50 years and and the visual arts
are barely even recognizable as art
anymore so maybe it's been the Saving
Grace of literature to be so
conservative but maybe it it will um
contribute to its death I don't know
